What are the three layers of Software Engineering (SE) as a layered technology?
Which layer serves as the foundation in Software Engineering's layered technology?
What is the correct order of the layers in Software Engineering?
What does the 'Methods' layer in Software Engineering primarily focus on?
Defining the systematic approach to software development
Software Engineering follows a layered technology model, which consists of processes, methods, and tools.
Tools are the foundation of Software Engineering's layered approach.
Methods in Software Engineering are responsible for structuring the development process.
Software Engineering does not require any structured layers; it can be performed randomly.
What is the fundamental layer in the layered technology of Software Engineering?
Which of the following is NOT a function of the process layer in software engineering?
Lays the groundwork for software engineering
Provides a framework for software project management
Which layer in the layered technology focuses on requirement analysis, design modeling, and software testing?
What is the main purpose of the Tools layer in software engineering?
Provide automated or semi-automated support for software development
What is Computer-Aided Software Engineering (CASE) mainly used for?
Integrating software, hardware, and database tools
The Process layer is responsible for defining specific tools used in software engineering.
Methods in Software Engineering include activities such as requirement analysis, design modeling, and software testing.
Tools in the layered technology of Software Engineering can be automated or semi-automated to enhance development speed.
The Process layer does not influence project deadlines or quality standards.
Computer-Aided Software Engineering (CASE) tools only focus on software development and do not include hardware or databases.
What is an activity in the software process?
A general objective independent of project size or complexity
A set of tasks that deliver a major work product
A phase in the software development lifecycle
Which of the following best describes an action in the software process?
A step that involves planning a project
A document used for software modeling
Which activity in the software process framework focuses on exchanging views between the customer and the software engineer?
What is the primary purpose of the planning activity in the software process?
Defining scheduled tasks, projected risks, and required resources
Configuring software for the end user
Which software process activity involves creating prototypes or rough drafts to understand user requirements?
Which phase of the software process involves code generation and testing?
What is the main goal of the deployment phase in software development?
Configuring and evaluating the software at the user end
An activity in the software process is a specific, well-defined task.
Communication in the software process focuses on exchanging views between customers and software engineers to define requirements.
Planning in the software process involves coding and debugging.
Modeling refers to designing prototypes or drafts to help understand user requirements.
The construction phase in the software process includes code generation and testing.
Deployment involves configuring software at the user end and gathering feedback.
What is the goal of a software engineering project?
Writing as much code as possible
Reducing the number of engineers required
Which of the following is an example of a work product in software engineering?

Resources like participants, time, and equipment
What does the software engineering process ultimately produce?
Work products like system models and documents
A software engineering project consists of activities (phases) plus actions.
Tasks in software engineering do not consume any resources.
A work product in software engineering can include system models and documentation.
Software engineering does not require time or participants as resources.
Tasks in software engineering only produce software code, nothing else.
What does the term 'System' refer to in software engineering?
The underlying reality that the software interacts with
Which of the following is an example of a system in software engineering?

What does the term 'Model' refer to in software engineering?
A working prototype of a product
An abstraction of reality, a design, or a pattern

What is a work product in software development?
A physical object used in coding
An artifact produced during the development process
A system in software engineering refers to an abstract representation of a product.
A model in software engineering can be a design, a pattern, or an abstraction of reality.
A work product is any artifact produced during the software development process.
Internal work products are intended for project teams and not for external clients.
A deliverable work product is created for the internal team only.

To aid in defining, analyzing, and communicating a set of concepts

Analysis, specification, design, verification, and validation

Models in software engineering replace the need for actual system implementation.
The purpose of system models includes verification and validation of a system.
What are resources in software engineering?
Tasks performed to achieve a goal
Code written for a software project
What is a task in software engineering?
An atomic unit of work that can be managed
What defines an activity in software engineering?
A set of tasks performed toward a specific purpose
Which of the following is an example of an activity in software engineering?
Debugging a single line of code

Controlling and monitoring the project to meet goals such as budget, deadline, and quality
Resources in software engineering refer to tasks performed during development.
A task is an atomic unit of work that can be managed.
Activities in software engineering are composed of multiple tasks that work toward a specific purpose.
An example of an activity is installing the system, which is part of the delivery process.
Project management in software engineering is unrelated to budget, deadlines, or quality.
What is a method in software engineering?
A collection of rules for representing a model
A single-use solution for a unique problem
A repeatable technique for solving a specific problem
A software tool used for debugging
Which of the following is an example of a method?

A graphical notation for designing user interfaces
A collection of methods for solving a class of problems

A graphical or textual set of rules for representing a model
Which of the following is an example of a notation?
Which of the following is an object-oriented notation used for representing models?
A method is a repeatable technique for solving a specific problem.
A methodology is a single method used to solve a specific problem.
A seafood cookbook is an example of a methodology.
Notation refers to a graphical or textual set of rules used to represent a model.
UML (Unified Modeling Language) is an example of a methodology.
What is one of the primary benefits of using a methodology in software development?
How does a methodology contribute to software documentation?

It makes documentation unnecessary by simplifying the process

It prevents changes from being made

Which of the following is NOT a reason to use a methodology in software development?
Makes the software more maintainable and consistent

A methodology makes software documentation unnecessary.
Software developed using a methodology is typically more maintainable and consistent.
Using a methodology makes the software less acceptable to users.
A software methodology is useful only during the testing phase of development.
Which of the following is an issue when choosing a methodology?

Which of the following is a cost associated with choosing a methodology?

Which of the following is NOT listed as a cost in choosing a methodology?

Staff training is not a significant cost when implementing a new methodology.

Which level of abstraction includes a collection of methods for solving a class of problems?
What analogy is used to describe specifying software problems and solutions?
What is UML primarily used for in software engineering?
Why is UML used in software development instead of hand-drawn artistic models?
Most developers are not artists, and UML provides standardized symbols
UML is easier to use for coding than drawing
It is required by all software companies
The increasing levels of abstraction in software development are Task, Technique, Method, and Methodology.
A technique, such as a UML Use Case Diagram, is a more abstract concept than a task.
Software specification and problem-solving are compared to cartoon strip writing.
UML is a graphical language used in object-oriented development to represent different system models.
UML is primarily used for coding rather than for modeling software systems.
What are the two main categories of UML diagrams?
Which type of diagram represents the dynamic behavior of a system?
Which UML diagram represents the static structure of a system?
What does the external perspective model?
The data flow between different modules
The context or environment of the system
The internal processes of the system
Which UML perspective focuses on how the system responds to events?
Which UML diagram shows the activities involved in a process?
What is the primary purpose of a use-case diagram?
To illustrate how the system interacts with users and external entities
To define the relationships between system components
Which UML diagram represents interactions between actors and the system?
Which UML diagram is used to visualize the flow of events within a system, including choices and iterations?
What does a sequence diagram show?
The interaction between actors and system components over time
The internal state of a system
The budget estimation of a project
UML diagrams are divided into structure and behavior diagrams.
Behavior diagrams focus on representing the static structure of a system.
A use-case diagram illustrates functional requirements by showing system interactions with external actors.
A state diagram is primarily used to represent static relationships between objects in a system.
Sequence diagrams and use-case diagrams both show interactions, but sequence diagrams focus on the interaction between system objects.
Activity diagrams help visualize processes, including choices, iterations, and concurrency.
The structural perspective in UML is concerned with how the system reacts to different events.
Use-case diagrams provide more detailed information about object interactions than sequence diagrams.
An interaction perspective models how a system's components interact with each other or external entities.
Class diagrams are part of the behavioral diagram category.
What does a use case diagram primarily represent?
The internal code structure of a system
The interactions between users (actors) and the system
The database schema of a system
The network architecture of a system
In a use case diagram, what symbol represents an actor?
What is the main purpose of primary actors in a use case diagram?
To initiate interactions with the system
To manage the relationships between use cases
Which of the following is a valid example of a use case?
What does the 'include' relationship signify in a use case diagram?
A use case that is optional and occurs under specific conditions
A dependency where the included use case is always executed with the base use case
A relationship that defines a generalization between use cases
A relationship that allows one use case to override another
What is the key characteristic of an 'extend' relationship?
The extended use case always executes
The extended use case only executes under specific conditions
The extended use case replaces the base use case
The extended use case runs before the base use case
Which of the following best describes 'generalization' in use case diagrams?
A hierarchical relationship where a specialized use case inherits behaviors from a general use case
A relationship where two use cases are executed together
A relationship where the general use case is optional
A connection between unrelated use cases
In the patient information system example, which actor is responsible for registering patients?
Which of the following is NOT an example of a valid use case in an inventory management system?
In the banking system use case diagram, when does the bank act?
Before the customer interacts with the system
Only after the customer initiates an action
As soon as the system starts
A use case diagram is primarily used to describe the system’s functional requirements.
A secondary actor in a use case diagram initiates the system's functions.
Use cases are represented by ovals in a use case diagram.
A use case must always have at least one actor interacting with it.
The 'include' relationship means that the base use case can function independently without the included use case.
The 'extend' relationship indicates that the extended use case is always executed when the base use case runs.
A generalization in a use case diagram defines a parent-child relationship between use cases.
The Medical Receptionist in a patient information system has multiple use cases associated with them, such as registering and viewing patient information.
In an inventory management system, adding equipment to a store is a valid use case.
A use case diagram can represent actors that are people, organizations, or external systems.
Which of the following is a key aspect of the requirements analysis phase in software development?
Defining the purpose of the system based on user needs
What is the primary goal of architectural (system) design?
Breaking down the system into simpler modules or components
Writing the final version of the source code
Conducting market analysis for the software
Managing financial costs of software development
What does the coding (implementation) phase involve?
Translating the object model into source code
Which of the following best describes the verification and validation phase?
Ensuring the software meets requirements and functions correctly
Adding additional features to the system
Installing the software on client devices
What is the purpose of the maintenance phase in software engineering?
To develop marketing strategies for the software
To fix faults and ensure the system remains functional
To redesign the system from scratch
To train employees on coding best practices
Functional requirements define constraints on the operation of a system.
Architectural design involves breaking the system down into smaller, more manageable modules or components.
The detailed design phase focuses on coding rather than creating an object model with precise descriptions.
Verification and validation ensure that the software meets requirements and works correctly.
System integration involves combining individual components to form a complete and functional system.
